ContentClassification.TableReference: Committee of Mortality of the Canadian Institute of Actuaries, “II. Canadian Assured Lives Tables, 1958-64”, Transactions of the Society of Actuaries, Reports (1967). Accessed: July, 2013 from http://www.soa.org/library/research/transactions-reports-of-mortality-moribidity-and-experience/1960-69/1967/january/tsr673.pdf
ContentClassification.TableDescription: 1958-64 Canadian Institute of Actuaries (CIA) – Female. Basis: Age Nearest Birthday. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age:105
ContentClassification.Comments: Study Data: The basic data were obtained from 25 companies, representing about 84% by amount of the life insurance in force in Canada. Experience of both medically examined and nonmedical issues combined for the period between the 1958 and 1964 policy anniversaries. Data submitted on an age at issue and policy year duration basis for the first five policy year durations and on an attained age basis for subsequent policy year durations. The male data were adequate for the construction of select and ultimate tables, but the female data were inadequate for the preparation of select rates. NOTE: When initially published, the tables were referred to as “Canadian Assured Lives” Tables. For consistency with later tables, the word “assured” has been dropped from the table’s name. Methodology: For the main range of ages of the ultimate male data (policy year durations 6 and subsequent), a Whittaker-Henderson B formula was used to graduate the rates of mortality based on the experience by amounts. For the main range of ages of the ultimate female data (durations 6 and subsequent), a Whittaker-Henderson B formula was also used to graduate rates of mortality based on the experience by number of policies. Because there were fewer data on female lives, it was found that a graduation by policies produced a table which more adequately expressed the mortality of female lives. For the male select rates, King's method of constructing select rates was used, as described in the Journal of the Institute of Actuaries, Volume LIII. Graduation was designed to provide a reasonably close fit to the basic data and the tables therefore reflect actual experience for the period of study with no built-in mortality margins. Data Transcription Errors Detected: 07/2013. Data Corrected and Certified: 07/2013

MetaData.TableDescription: 1958-64 Canadian Institute of Actuaries (CIA) – Female. Basis: Age Nearest Birthday. Minimum Age: 0 Maximum Age:105
